facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1040 of 1965 filed by the Collector of Varanasi.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1040 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 11, 1963 of the Allahabad High Court in First Appeal No. 60 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave under Article 136 against Allahabad High Court judgment dated November 11, 1963 in First Appeal No. 60 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 11, 1963 of the Allahabad High Court in First Appeal No. 60 of 1960. B. Agarwala and 0. P. Rana, for the appellant.

facts.text: First Appeal No. 60 of 1960 arose from award by Shri S. B. Malik, District Judge, Varanasi under clause b of sub-section 1 of section 19 of Defence of India Act, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 11, 1963 of the Allahabad High Court in First Appeal No. 60 of 1960 on its file, which in its turn arose from the award made by Shri S. B. Malik, District Judge, Varanasi, in certain land acquisition proceedings under cl.  b  of sub-s.  1  of s . 19 of the Defence of India Act, 1939  to be hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Government acquired about 500 acres of land in 1946 for constructing Babatpur aerodrome near Varanasi.

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of constructing the Babatpur aerodrome near Varanasi, the Government acquired in the year 1946 about 500 acres of land. Compensation in respect of most of the lands acquired was settled by agreement.

facts.text: Compensation for most acquired lands settled by agreement.

anchor.surface_text: Compensation in respect of most of the lands acquired was settled by agreement. But in respect of the lands with which we are concerned in this appeal, 48.01 acres in extent, no settlement was arrived at.

facts.text: 48.01 acres of land no compensation settlement, referred to arbitration of Shri S. B. Malik.

anchor.surface_text: But in respect of the lands with which we are concerned in this appeal, 48.01 acres in extent, nosettlement was arrived at. Therefore, the question of compensation in respect of those lands was referred to the arbitration of Shri S. B. Malik under cl.  b  of sub-s.  1  of s. 19 of the Act.

facts.text: Claimants entitled to market value as on date of acquisition per section 19(1)(e).

anchor.surface_text: In view of s. 19 1  e , the claimants were entitled to get as compensation the market value of those lands as on the date of acquisition.

facts.text: Parties agreed market value to be fixed on sale deeds or capitalizing annual profits.

anchor.surface_text: Before the arbitrator as well as the High Court, the parties were agreed that on the material on the record, the market value in question had to be fixed either on the basis of the sale deeds produced by the claimants or by capitalising the annual profits accruing from those lands.

facts.text: Arbitrator rejected sale deeds produced by claimants.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrator rejected the sale deeds produced before him. He adopted the method of capitalising the annual profits.

facts.text: Arbitrator determined annual profits based on revenue records for Fasli 1355 and evidence of Naib Tehsildar Jawal Prasad.

anchor.surface_text: On the question of annual profits also he rejected the evidence adduced on behalf of the claimants. He determined the same on the basis of the revenue records for Fasli 1355 read with the evidence of the Naib Tehsildar, Jawal Prasad.

facts.text: Arbitrator fixed compensation at Rs. 26,454-12-0.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrator had fixed the compensation at Rs. 26,454-12-0. The High Court enhanced the same to Rs. 90,446-3-0.

facts.text: Claimants appealed to Allahabad High Court under section 19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by the decision of the arbitrator, the claimants went up in appeal to the High Court of Allahabad under s. 19 1  f .

facts.text: High Court accepted sale deeds as reliable, fixed compensation based on Exh. A-42 dated 3-4-1951, enhanced to Rs. 90,446-3-0.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court differed from the arbitrator as to the value to be attached to the sale deeds produced. It opined that the sale deeds produced were reliable and that they evidenced genuine transactions. The High Court fixed the compensation payable on the basis of Exh. A 42 dated 3-4-1951.

facts.text: Acquisitions made in Fasli 1354.

anchor.surface_text: The acquisitions in question were made in fasli 1354.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave under Article 136.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by the Collector of Varanasi by special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution, is directed against the decision dated 11-11-1963 of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad, in First Appeal No. 60 of 1960 on its file,

facts.text: Shri S. B. Malik was District Judge of Varanasi at time of appointment as arbitrator.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Malik who possessed the required qualifications was appointed by the Central Government to act as an arbitrator it is true that Shri Malik was District Judge of Varanasi at the time of his appointment,

facts.text: After second world war, price of landed property went up steeply.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrator has found that after the close of the second world war, the price of landed property had gone up steeply. This finding does not appear to have been challenged before the High Court.

facts.text: Exh. A-42 sale of 0.26 acres in 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Further, under the deed in question, the land sold was .26 acres in extent. The price fetched by such a tiny bit of land is of noassistance in determining the value of the lands acquired.

facts.text: Exh. 35 sale on 10-6-1947 of 0.28 acres to one of the claimants.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondents, we were asked to determine the compensation of the lands acquired on the basis of sale deed Exh. 35 which relates to a sale that took place on 10-6-1947 which according to the respondents can be considered as a contemporaneous sale.

facts.text: Village papers of Fasli 1355 produced, not 1354.

anchor.surface_text: For reasons not disclosed. the village papers of 1354 fasli were not produced by the appellant. On the other hand, the village papers of 1355 fasli were produced.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court decision and remits case back for fresh disposal.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above, we allow this appeal and set aside the decision of the High Court and remit the case back to that Court for disposal according to law.

facts.text: High Court to permit additional evidence on contemporaneous sale deeds and Fasli 1354 records.

anchor.surface_text: Before deciding the case afresh the High Court will permit the parties, to adduce additional evidence on the question of compensation in particular, they will be allowed to produce and prove contemporaneous sale deeds and the revenue records relating to fasli 1354.

issues.text: Whether special leave could have been granted by this Court under Art. 136 as the judgment appealed against was neither that of a court nor of a tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: that this Court could not have granted special leave under Art. 136 as the judgment appealed against was neither that of a court nor of a tribunal.

issues.text: Whether the High Court while acting under s. 19(1)(f) was a persona designata and not a court or a tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: According to him, the High Court while acting under s. 19 1  f  was a persona designata and not a court or a tribunal.

issues.text: Whether the real question is whether the decision in Hanskumar Kishanchand lays down the law correctly that a High Court while acting under s. 19(1)(f) is not functioning as a court.

anchor.surface_text: The rule is well settled that when a statute directs that an appeal shall lie to a court already established, then that appeal must be regulated by the practice and procedure of that court.

issues.text: Whether the High Court erred in law in awarding compensation on the basis of Exh. 42.

anchor.surface_text: In view of s. 19 1  e , the claimants were entitled to get as compensation the market value of those lands as on the date of acquisition.

arguments.claim: No special leave could have been granted under Art. 136 as the High Court judgment was neither that of a court nor of a tribunal

anchor.surface_text: Shri Goyal, learned counsel for the respondents has raised the preliminary objection that no special leave could have been granted by this Court under Art. 136 as the judgment appealed against was neither that of a court nor of a tribunal.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: brought on the strength of the certificates issued  1  1963 Supp. 1 S.C.R. 625 2  1959 S.C.R. 1177. by the High Court on 25th August 1949 under ss. 10

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court functions as court under s.19(1)(f); distinguishes Hanskumar; applies established court procedure rule

arguments.claim: High Court under s.19(1)(f) was a persona designata and not a court or tribunal

arguments.claim: Arbitrator under s.19(1)(b) is designated person not court; being District Judge coincidental

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 19 1  b  of the Act empowers the Central Government to appoint as arbitrator a person qualified to be appointed a judge of the High Court Shri Malik who possessed the required qualifications was appointed by the Central Government to act as an arbitrator it is true that Shri Malik was District Judge of Varanasi at the time of his appointment,

arguments.claim: Appeal under s.19(1)(f) continues arbitration character; HC decision is award not judgment

anchor.surface_text: when the matter was taken up in appeal to the High Court, the proceedings did not cease to be arbitration proceedings its original character continued even before the High Court therefore, the decision made by the High Court should also be considered as an award and further the High Court in making that award should be considered as having functioned as an arbitrator.

anchor.surface_text: In support of his contention that the High Court while acting under s. 19  1  f  was not functioning as a court, he placed strong reliance on the decision of this Court in Hanskumar Kishanchand v. Union of India 2 . That case dealt with two cross appeals arising from a decision of the Nagpur High Court under s. 19 1  f .

arguments.court_reasoning: Exh.42 from 1951, not contemporaneous; tiny plot 0.26 acres; prices rose post-WWII

arguments.court_reasoning: Tiny plot 0.28 acres; vendee is claimant; no evidence on nature of land

arguments.claim: High Court functions as court under s.19(1)(f) as appeal to established court follows its procedure

anchor.surface_text: The rule is well settled that when a statute directs that an appeal shall lie to a court already established, then that appeal must be regulated by the practice and procedure of that court.

arguments.claim: Hanskumar incorrectly held High Court under s.19(1)(f) not a court

anchor.surface_text: We may not turn our attention to the decision of this Court in Hanskumar Kishanchand v. Union of India 3  on which, as mentioned earlier, Shri Goyal placed a great deal of reliance in support of his preliminary objection.

arguments.qualifiers: With respect to the learned Judges

arguments.claim: High Court is court of record at apex of judicial system; always functions as court

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie it appears incongruous to hold that the High Court is not a court. The High Court of a State is at the apex of the States judicial system. It is a court of record.

arguments.claim: None of sale deeds reliable for compensation as not similar lands or contemporaneous

anchor.surface_text: We are also of the opinion that none of the sale deeds produced in this case can afford any assistance in determining the compensation payable to the respondents. They do not evidence sales of lands similar to the acquired lands, at about the time of the acquisition.

arguments.claim: Village papers of Fasli 1355 inappropriate as acquisitions in 1354; High Court rightly rejected

anchor.surface_text: For reasons not disclosed. the village papers of 1354 fasli were not produced by the appellant. On the other hand, the village papers of 1355 fasli were produced. In the first place, those records do not show the rent payable in the year in which the acquisitions took place.

holdings.text: The High Court while acting under s. 19(1)(f) functions as a court and not as a persona designata.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment, while acting under s. 19 1  f , the High Court functions as a court and not as a designated person. Our conclusion in this regard receives support from the decision of the Judicial Committee in Secretary of State for India in Council v. Chelikani Rama Rao

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appeal to established court like High Court regulated by its practice and procedure; High Court is court of record; distinguishes Hanskumar as not addressing Art.136 and lacking basis.

holdings.text: The decision rendered by the High Court under s. 19(1)(f) is a determination amenable to special leave under Art. 136.

anchor.surface_text: We have already come to the conclusion that the decision rendered by the High Court under s. 19 1  f  is a determination. Hence, it was within the competence of this Court to grant special leave under Art. 136.

holdings.reasoning_summary: HC functions as court; its determination falls within Art.136 scope.

holdings.text: The decision in Hanskumar Kishanchand v. Union of India does not lay down the correct law that High Court under s.19(1)(f) is not functioning as a court.

anchor.surface_text: With respect to the learned Judges who decided that case, we are unable to agree with that conclusion. In our judgment, while acting under s. 19 1  f , the High Court functions as a court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hanskumar concerned CPC ss.109-110, not Art.136; relied on cases not supporting conclusion that HC not court; no sound basis for that view.

holdings.text: Provisions of Art. 133 not attracted to HC decision under s.19(1)(f); no certificate required; O.13 R.2 not bar to special leave.

anchor.surface_text: As seen earlier, this Court ruled in Hanskumar Kishanchand v. Union of India that the decision rendered by the High Court under s. 19 1  f  is not a decree, judgment or final order. Hence, the provisions of Art. 133 are not attracted

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per Hanskumar, HC decision not judgment/decree/final order under Art.133; exemption from O.13 R.2 granted.

holdings.text: High Court erred in law in awarding compensation on basis of Exh. A-42.

anchor.surface_text: All that we need say is that the High Court was not right in determining the compensation payable to the respondents on the basis of Exh. 42. Hence its decision cannot be sustained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exh.42 dated 1951, not contemporaneous (acquisition 1946/Fasli 1354); post-WWII price rise; tiny 0.26 acre plot not comparable.

holdings.text: None of the sale deeds produced afford assistance in determining compensation as not similar lands or contemporaneous.

anchor.surface_text: We are also of the opinion that none of the sale deeds produced in this case can afford any assistance in determining the compensation payable to the respondents. They do not evidence sales of lands similar to the acquired lands, at about the time

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sale deeds like Exh.35 (1947, 0.28 acres to claimant, nature unknown) and others not comparable in size, time, similarity.

holdings.text: Village papers of Fasli 1355 inappropriate for annual profits as acquisitions in Fasli 1354.

anchor.surface_text: For reasons not disclosed. the village papers of 1354 fasli were not produced by the appellant. On the other hand, the village papers of 1355 fasli were produced. In the first place, those records do not show the rent payable in the year

holdings.reasoning_summary: Records must relate to year of acquisition (Fasli 1354); 1355 subsequent.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; High Court decision set aside; case remitted for fresh disposal permitting additional evidence on contemporaneous sales and Fasli 1354 records.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Errors in evidence evaluation; fresh determination needed by fact-finding court with better evidence.

precedents.citation: Engineering Mazdoor Sabha and another v. The Hind Cycles Ltd. 1 [1963 Supp. 1 S.C.R. 625]

anchor.surface_text: view of the decision of this Court in Engineering Mazdoor Sabha and another v. The Hind Cycles Ltd. 1 . In support of his contention that the High Court while acting under s. 19 (1) (f) was not functioning as a court, he placed strong reliance on the decision of this Court in Hanskumar Kishanchand v. Union of India 2 .

precedents.case_name: Engineering Mazdoor Sabha v Hind Cycles Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: the decision of the High Court is a determination as contemplated in Art. 136

precedents.citation: Hanskumar Kishanchand v. Union of India 2 [1959 S.C.R. 1177]

anchor.surface_text: reliance on the decision of this Court in Hanskumar Kishanchand v. Union of India 2 . That case dealt with two cross appeals arising from a decision of the Nagpur High Court under s. 19 (1) (f). Those appeals were brought on the strength of the certificates issued by the High Court on 25th August 1949 under ss. 109 and 110 of the Civil Procedure Code.

precedents.case_name: Hanskumar Kishanchand v Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court acting under s. 19(1)(f) is persona designata and not a court
precedents.cited_holding: provision for appeal to the High Court under s. 19(1)(f) can only be construed as a reference to it as an authority designated and not as a court

precedents.citation: National Telephone Co., Ltd. v. Postmaster-General 1 [1913 A.C. 546]

anchor.surface_text: The rule is well settled that when a statute directs that an appeal shall lie to a court already established, then that appeal must be regulated by the practice and procedure of that court. This rule was stated by Viscount Haldane L. C. in National Telephone Co., Ltd. v. Postmaster-General 1 thus

precedents.case_name: National Telephone Co Ltd v Postmaster-General
precedents.cited_proposition: when a question is referred to an established court, the ordinary incidents of the procedure of that court attach, and general right of appeal from its decision attaches

precedents.citation: National Sewing Thread Co., Ltd., v. James Chadwick and Bros. Ltd. 1 [1953 S.C.R. 1028]

anchor.surface_text: This statement of the law was accepted as correct by this Court in National Sewing Thread Co., Ltd., v. James Chadwick and Bros. Ltd. 1 . It may be noted that the appeal provided in s. 19(1)(f) is an appeal to the High Court and not to any Judge of the High Court.

precedents.case_name: National Sewing Thread Co Ltd v James Chadwick and Bros Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: statement of law in National Telephone case accepted as correct

precedents.case_name: Associated Cement Companies Ltd v P N Sharma
precedents.cited_proposition: definition of court as tribunal constituted by State as part of ordinary hierarchy invested with judicial powers

anchor.surface_text: Our conclusion in this regard receives support from the decision of the Judicial Committee in Secretary of State for India in Council v. Chelikani Rama Rao 1 and others referred to earlier. Dealing with the ratio of its decision in Rangoon Botatoung Co. case 2 ,

precedents.case_name: Secretary of State v Chelikani Rama Rao
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court functions as court even in statutory appeals from arbitrators

precedents.citation: Rangoon Botatoung Co. v. The Collector, Rangoon 2 [39 I.A. 197]

anchor.surface_text: Dealing with the ratio of its decision in Rangoon Botatoung Co. v. The Collector, Rangoon 2 enounced a principle which formed a precedent for excluding all appeal from the decision of the District Court in such cases as the present.

precedents.case_name: Rangoon Botatoung Co v Collector Rangoon
precedents.cited_proposition: no further appeal from statutory arbitration courts

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; decision of High Court set aside; case remitted to High Court for fresh disposal permitting parties to adduce additional evidence on compensation including contemporaneous sale deeds and revenue records of fasli 1354
directions: Before deciding the case afresh the High Court will permit the parties to adduce additional evidence on the question of compensation in particular, they will be allowed to produce and prove contemporaneous sale deeds and the revenue records relating to fasli 1354
Costs of this appeal shall be costs in the cause
